text: 1 Tutorial 1 1- Water enters a 2.5 cm internal diameter thin copper tube of a heat exchanger at 15â„ƒ at a rate of 0.3 kg/s, and is heated by steam condensing outside at 120â„ƒ. If the average heat transfer coefficient is 800 ğ‘Š ğ‘š2.â„ƒ, determine the length of the tube in order to heat the water to 115â„ƒ (see the figure). Solution: Water is heated by steam in a circular tube. The tube length required to heat the water to a specified temperature is to be determined. Assumptions: 1- Steady operating conditions exit 2- Fluid properties are constant 3- The convection heat transfer coefficient is constant 4- The conduction resistance of copper tube is negligible so that the inner surface temperature of the tube is equal to the condensation temperature of steam. Properties The specific heat of water at the bulk mean temperature of (15+115)/2=65â„ƒ is 4187 J/kg.â„ƒ. The heat of condensation of steam at 120â„ƒ is 2203 kJ/kg. Analysis Knowing the inlet and exit temperatures of water, the rate of heat transfer is determined to be ğ‘„Ì‡ = ğ‘š Ì‡ ğ‘ğ‘(ğ‘‡ğ‘’ âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘–) = (0.3 ğ‘˜ğ‘” ğ‘  ) (4.187 ğ‘˜ğ½ ğ‘˜ğ‘”â„ƒ ) (115â„ƒ âˆ’ 15â„ƒ) = 125.6ğ‘˜ğ‘Š The logarithmic mean temperature difference is âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘’ = ğ‘‡ğ‘  âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘’=120â„ƒ âˆ’ 115â„ƒ = 5â„ƒ âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘– = ğ‘‡ğ‘  âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘–=120â„ƒ âˆ’ 15â„ƒ = 105â„ƒ âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ‘š = âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘’ âˆ’ âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘– ln ( 5 105) = 5 âˆ’ 105 ln (5/105) = 32.85â„ƒ The heat transfer surface area is ğ‘„Ì‡ = â„ğ´ğ‘ âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ‘š â†’ ğ´ğ‘  = ğ‘„Ì‡ â„âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ‘š = 125.6 ğ‘˜ğ‘Š (0.8 ğ‘˜ğ‘Š ğ‘š2. â„ƒ)(32.85â„ƒ) = 4.78ğ‘š2 Then the required tube length becomes 2 ğ´ğ‘  = ğœ‹ğ·ğ¿ â†’ ğ¿ = ğ´ğ‘  ğœ‹ğ· = 4.78 ğ‘š2 ğœ‹(0.025ğ‘š) = 61ğ‘š Discussion: The bulk mean temperature of water during this heating process is 65â„ƒ, and thus the arithmetic mean temperature difference is âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘š =120-65=55â„ƒ. Using âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘š instead of âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ‘š would give L= 36m, which is grossly in error. This shows the importance of using the logarithmic mean temperature in calculations. 2- Compare the hydrodynamic and thermal entry lengths of mercury (liquid metal) and a light oil flowing at 3.0 mm/s in a 25.0 mm diameter smooth tube at a bulk temperature of 750C. The pertinent parameters of the fluids at that temperature are: ğ‘£ğ»ğ‘”=1.0 Ã— 10âˆ’7 m 2/s, ğ‘£ğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘™=6.5 Ã— 10âˆ’6 m 2/s, ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ»ğ‘” = 0.019, ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘™ = 85. Solution: The Reynolds numbers based on the tube diameters are: ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ»ğ‘” = ğ‘‰ğ· ğ‘£ğ»ğ‘” = (3.0 Ã— 10âˆ’3ğ‘š/ğ‘ )(25.0 Ã— 10âˆ’3ğ‘š) 1.0 Ã— 10âˆ’7 ğ‘š2/ğ‘  = 750 ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘™ = ğ‘‰ğ· ğ‘£ğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘™ = (3.0 Ã— 10âˆ’3ğ‘š/ğ‘ )(25.0 Ã— 10âˆ’3ğ‘š) 6.5 Ã— 10âˆ’6 ğ‘š2/ğ‘  = 11.53 The hydrodynamic entry lengths are given by ( ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘‘,â„ ğ· ) â‰ˆ 0.05ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ· so ğ‘¥â„,ğ»ğ‘” â‰ˆ (0.05)(750)(25.0ğ‘šğ‘š) = 937.5 ğ‘šğ‘š ğ‘¥â„,ğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘™ â‰ˆ (0.05)(11.53)(25.0ğ‘šğ‘š) = 14.4 ğ‘šğ‘š For the thermal entry lengths, ( ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘‘,ğ‘¡ ğ· )ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘š â‰ˆ 0.05ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ·ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ ğ‘¥ğ‘¡,ğ»ğ‘” â‰ˆ (0.05)(750)(0.019)(25.0ğ‘šğ‘š) = 17.8 ğ‘šğ‘š ğ‘¥ğ‘¡,ğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘™ â‰ˆ (0.05)(11.53)(85)(25.0ğ‘šğ‘š) = 1225 ğ‘šğ‘š Note the short thermal entry of mercury compared to its hydrodynamic entry lengths. What has caused this significant difference? 3- For heating water from 20Â°C to 60Â°C an electrically heated tube resulting in a constant heat flux of 10 kW/m 2 is proposed. The mass flow rate is to be such that ReD=2000, and consequently the flow must remain laminar. The tube inside diameter is 25mm. The flow is fully developed (velocity profile). Determine (a) the length of tube required and (b) if thus proposed heating system is feasible with regard to wall temperature. Solution We first calculate the average temperature which is ğ‘‡Ì… â„=20+60 2 Â°ğ¶=40â„ƒ The thermo-physical properties should be evaluated (from the table) at this average temperature ğœŒ = 994.6 ğ‘˜ğ‘” ğ‘š3 ğ¶ğ‘ = 4.1784 ğ‘˜ğ½ ğ‘˜ğ‘”.ğ¾ 3 Pr=4.34 k= 0.628 W/m.K ğœˆ=0.658Ã— 10âˆ’6 ğ‘š2/ğ‘  (a) The required tube length is obtained by an energy balance, i.e., ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘£ = ğ‘šÌ‡ ğ‘ğ‘(ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘œ âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘–) = ğ‘â€²â€²(ğ´ğ‘ ) To determine ğ‘šÌ‡ we need to know the bulk velocity. Since ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ· = 2000, ğ·ğ‘‰ ğœˆ = 2000; ğ‘‰ = 2000 ğ‘£ ğ· = 2000(0.658Ã—10âˆ’6 ğ‘š2/ğ‘ ) 0.025 ğ‘š = 0.0526 ğ‘š/ğ‘  and ğ‘šÌ‡ ğ¶ğ‘=ğœŒğ‘‰ ( ğœ‹ğ·2 4 ) (ğ‘ğ‘) = ( 994.6 ğ‘˜ğ‘” ğ‘š3 ) (0.0526 ğ‘š ğ‘  ) ( ğœ‹ 4) Ã— (0.025 ğ‘š)2 (4178 ğ½ ğ‘˜ğ‘”.ğ¾) = 107.3 ğ‘Š/ğ¾ Rearranging expression (i) we have ğ´ğ‘ =ğœ‹ğ·ğ¿ğ‘ â€²â€² =ğ‘šÌ‡ ğ‘ğ‘(ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘œ âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘–); ğ¿ = ğ‘šÌ‡ ğ‘ğ‘(ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘œâˆ’ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘–) ğœ‹ğ·ğ‘,, Inserting numerical values with ğ‘šÌ‡ ğ‘ğ‘ from expression (ii) yields ğ¿ = (107.3 ğ‘Š/ğ¾)(60Â°ğ¶âˆ’20â„ƒ) ğœ‹(0.025ğ‘š)(10000 ğ‘Š/ğ‘š2) = 5.46 ğ‘š (b) Is this flow feasible? Is the wall temperature realistic? With the flow being hydrodynamically fully developed, we check the length of the thermal entry section given by ğ‘¥ğ‘¡,ğ‘“ğ‘‘ = 0.05ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ·ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ· = 0.05(2000)(4.34)(0.025m)=10.85m and clearly this is a case of constant ğ‘â€²â€²; developed velocity and developing thermal profile. The Nusselt number may be obtained from the Figures below The inverse of Graetz number at the exit is ğºğ‘§âˆ’1 = (ğ‘¥ ğ·) ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ·ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ = (5.46 ğ‘š/0.025ğ‘š)/ (2000)(4.34)=0.0252=2.52Ã— 10âˆ’2 and reading the dashed line for constant surface heat flux in the figure above, Nu=5.0 4 where this is the local value at the tube exit where the wall temperature will be maximum. Hence, â„ = ğ‘˜ ğ· ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ· = (0.628 ğ‘Š ğ‘šğ¾. 0.025 ğ‘š ) (5.0) = 125.6 ğ‘Š ğ‘š2.ğ‘˜ Then with known ğ‘â€²â€², ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘– and h, the exit plane surface temperature is ğ‘â€²â€² = â„(ğ‘‡ğ‘  âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘œ); ğ‘‡ğ‘ =ğ‘,, â„ + ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘œ ğ‘‡ğ‘  = 10 ğ‘˜ğ‘Š ğ‘š2 ( 1 125.6 ğ‘Š ğ‘š2.ğ¾) + 60â„ƒ ğ‘‡ğ‘  = 139.6â„ƒ â‰ˆ 412 ğ¾ This is slightly high temperature for the wall material. If necessary, the wall heat flux could be reduced thereby lengthening the tube, increasing the Greatz-1number, and lowering ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ· and h very slightly. The ğ‘‡ğ‘  is more affected by the ğ‘â€²â€² than the h, for example a 50% reduction in ğ‘â€²â€² would lower ğ‘‡ğ‘ ,ğ‘œ by approximetly 35â„ƒ. 4-Air at 1.0 atmosphere pressure and 77Â°C enters a 5.0 mm i.d. tube with a bulk average velocity of 2.5 m/s. The velcoity profile is developed and the thermal profile is â€œdevelopingâ€. The tube length is 1.0 m, and a constant (uniform) heat flux is imposed by the tube surface on the air over the entire length. An exit air bulk average temperature, Th.o=127Â°C, is required. Determine (a) the exit h value, hL, (b) the uniform qsâ€™â€™, and (c) the exit tube surface temperature. We will need air properties at the bulk average temperature inside the tube, ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘–+ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘œ 2 = (77+127) 2 = 102â„ƒ=375 K From property tables we obtain ğœŒ = 0.9403 ğ‘˜ğ‘”/ğ‘š3 ğ‘ğ‘ = 1.0115 ğ‘˜ğ½ ğ‘˜ğ‘”. ğ¾ ğœ‡ = 2.1805 Ã— 10âˆ’5 Kg/m.s ğœˆ = 23.33 Ã— 10âˆ’6 ğ‘š2/ğ‘  k= 0.03184 W/m.K Pr=0.693 The Reynolds number is ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ· = ğ·ğ‘‰ ğ‘£ = (0.005 ğ‘š)(2.5 ğ‘š/ğ‘ ) 23.33Ã—10âˆ’6 ğ‘š2/ğ‘  =536 and the flow is laminar. The thermal entry length is (ğ‘¥ğ‘¡,ğ‘“ğ‘‘/D)=0.05ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ·(ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ) = 26.8(0.693) = 18.6 The L/D for this tube is (1.0/0.005) which is 200. A reasonable approach is to consider the flow, both velocity and temperature, to be fully developed over its entire tube length, since only about 10% is experiencing entry effects. For fully developed flow, constant ğ‘â€²â€², the Nusselt number is 4.36, so 5 ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ· = â„ğ· ğ‘˜ = 4.364 â„ = 4.364 ğ‘˜ ğ· = 4.364 (0.03184 ğ‘Š ğ‘š.ğ¾) 0.005 ğ‘š = 27.79 W/ğ‘š2. ğ¾ = â„ğ¿ = â„ = ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘¡ Use an overall energy balance ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘£ = ğ‘â€²â€²(ğ´ğ‘ ) = ğ‘šÌ‡ ğ‘ğ‘(ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘œ âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘,ğ‘–) where ğ´ğ‘  = ğœ‹ğ·ğ¿ = ğœ‹(0.005ğ‘š)(1 ğ‘š)=1.57 Ã— 10âˆ’2ğ‘š2 5- Consider the flow of oil at 200C in a 30-cm- diameter pipeline at an average velocity of 2 m/s (see the figure below). A 200-m-long section of the horizontal pipeline passes through icy waters of a lake at 00C. Measurements indicate that the surface temperature of the pipe is very nearly 00C. Disregarding the thermal resistance of the pipe material, determine (a) the temperature of the oil when the pipe leaves the lake (b) the rate of heat transfer from the oil, (c) the pumping power required to overcome the pressure losses and to maintain the flow of the oil in the pipe. Oil flows in a pipeline that passes through icy waters of a lake at 0â„ƒ. The exit temperature of the oil, the rate of heat loss, and the pumping power needed to overcome pressure losses are to be determined. Assumptions: 1- Steady operating conditions exits 2- The surface temperature of the pipe is very nearly 0â„ƒ 3- The thermal resistance of the pipe is negligible. 4- The inner surfaces of the pipeline are smooth 5- The flow is hydrodynamically developed when the pipeline reaches the lake. Properties: we do not know the exit temperature of the oil, and thus we cannot determine the bulk mean temperature, which is the temperature at which the properties of oil are to be evaluated. The mean temperature of the oil at the inlet is 20â„ƒ, and we expect this temperature to drop somewhat as a result of heat loss to the icy waters of the lake. We evalaute the properties of the oil at the inlet temeparture, but we will repeat the calculations, if necessary, using properties at the evaluated bulk mean temperature. At 20â„ƒ we read ğœŒ = 888.1 ğ‘˜ğ‘”/ğ‘š3 ğ‘£ = 9.429 Ã— 10âˆ’4 ğ‘š2/s k= 0.145 W/m.â„ƒ ğ‘ğ‘=1880 J/ kg.â„ƒ Pr=10,863 6 Analysis: (a) The Reynolds number is ğ‘…ğ‘’ = ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”ğ· ğ‘£ = (2 ğ‘š/ğ‘ )(0.3ğ‘š) 9.429 Ã— 10âˆ’4ğ‘š2/ğ‘  = 636 Which is less than the critical Reynolds number and hence the flow is laminar. The thermal, entry length in this case is roughly ğ‘¥ğ‘¡,ğ‘“ğ‘‘ â‰ˆ 0.05ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ· = 0.05 Ã— 636 Ã— 10863 Ã— (0.3ğ‘š) â‰ˆ 103600ğ‘š which is much greater than the total length of the pipe. This is typical of fluids with high Prandtl numbers. Therefore, we assume thermally developing flow and determine the Nusselt number from ğ‘ğ‘¢=â„ğ· ğ‘˜ = 3.66 + 0.065(ğ· ğ¿)ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ 1+0.04[(ğ· ğ¿)ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ] 2 3 = 3.66 + 0.065( 0.3 200) Ã— 636 Ã— 10,863 1 + 0.04[(0.3/200) Ã— 636 Ã— 10863]2/3 = 33.7 Note that this Nusselt number is considerably higher than the fully developed value of 3.66. Then â„ = ğ‘˜ ğ· ğ‘ğ‘¢ = 0.145 ğ‘Š ğ‘šâ„ƒ 0.3 ğ‘š (33.7) = 16.3 ğ‘Š/ğ‘š2â„ƒ Also, ğ‘‡ğ‘’ = ğ‘‡ğ‘  âˆ’ (ğ‘‡ğ‘  âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘–)exp (âˆ’â„ğ´ğ‘ /ğ‘šÌ‡ ğ¶ğ‘) = 0â„ƒ âˆ’ [(0 âˆ’ 20)â„ƒ] exp [âˆ’ (163 ğ‘Š ğ‘š2â„ƒ ) (188.5 ğ‘š2) (125.6 ğ‘˜ğ‘” ğ‘  ) (1881 ğ½ ğ‘˜ğ‘” â„ƒ) ] = 19.74â„ƒ Thus, the mean temperature of oil drops by a mere 0.26â„ƒ as it crosses the lake. This makes the bulk mean oil temperature 19.87â„ƒ, which is practically identical to the inlet temperature of 20â„ƒ. Therefore, we do not need to re-evaluate the properties. (b) The logarithmic mean temperature difference and the rate of heat loss from the oil are âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ‘š = ğ‘‡ğ‘– âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘’ ğ‘™ğ‘› ğ‘‡ğ‘  âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘’ ğ‘‡ğ‘  âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘– = 20 âˆ’ 19.74 ğ‘™ğ‘› 0 âˆ’ 19.74 0 âˆ’ 20 = âˆ’19.87â„ƒ ğ‘„Ì‡ = â„ğ´ğ‘ âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ‘š = (16.3 ğ‘Š ğ‘š2 â„ƒ) (188.5ğ‘š2)(âˆ’19.87Â°ğ¶) = âˆ’6.11 Ã— 104ğ‘Š Therefore, the oil will lose heat at a rate of 61.1 kW as it flows through the pipe in the icy waters of the lake. Note that âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ‘› is identical to the arithmetic mean temeparture in this case, since âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘– â‰ˆ âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘’. (C) The laminar flow of oil is hydrodynamically developed. Therefore, the friction factor can be determined from ğ‘“ = 64 ğ‘…ğ‘’ = 64 636 = 0.1006 Then the pressure drop in the pipe and the required pumping power become 7 âˆ†ğ‘ƒ = ğ‘“ ğ¿ ğ· ğœŒğ‘‰2 2 = 0.1006 200 ğ‘š 0.3 ğ‘š (888.1 ğ‘˜ğ‘”/ğ‘š3)(2 ğ‘š/ğ‘ ) 2 2 = 1.19 Ã— 105ğ‘/ğ‘š2 ğ‘ŠÌ‡ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘ = (125.6 ğ‘˜ğ‘” ğ‘  )(1.19 Ã— 105ğ‘/ğ‘š2) 888.1 ğ‘˜ğ‘”/ğ‘š3 = 16.8 ğ‘˜ğ‘Š Discussion We need a 16.8 kW pipe just to overcome the friction in the pipe as the oil flows in 200 m long pipe through the lake. 6- Air at 2 atm and 200â„ƒ is heated as it flows through a tube with a diameter of 25.4 mm at a velocity of 10 m/s. Calculate the heat transfer per unit length of tube if a constant-heat- flux condition is maintained at the wall and the wall temperature is 20â„ƒ above the air temeparture, all along the length of the tube. How much the bulk temperature increase over a 3-m length of the tube? Solution We first evaluate the Reynolds number at the inlet bulk temperature to determine the flow regime. The properties of air at 200â„ƒ are ğœŒ = ğ‘ƒ ğ‘…ğ‘‡ = (2)(1.0132 Ã— 105) (287)(473) = 1.493 ğ‘˜ğ‘”/ğ‘š3 ğ‘ğ‘ = 1.025 ğ‘˜ğ½/ğ‘˜ğ‘”â„ƒ ğœ‡ = 2.57 Ã— 10âˆ’5 ğ‘˜ğ‘” ğ‘š.ğ‘  ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ = 0.681 ğ‘˜ = 0.0386 ğ‘Š/ğ‘šâ„ƒ ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘‘ = ğœŒğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘‘ ğœ‡ = (1.493)(10)(0.0254) 2.57 Ã— 10âˆ’5 = 14,756 so that the flow is turbulent. ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘‘ = â„ğ‘‘ ğ‘˜ = 0.023ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘‘ 0.8ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ0.4 = (0.023)(14756)0.8(0.681)0.4 = 42.67 â„ = ğ‘˜ ğ‘‘ ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘‘ = (0.0386)(42.67) 0.0254 = 64.85 ğ‘Š/ğ‘š2â„ƒ The heat flow per unit length is then ğ‘ ğ¿ = â„ğœ‹ğ‘‘(ğ‘‡ğ‘  âˆ’ ğ‘‡ğ‘) = (64.85)ğœ‹(0.0254)(20) = 103.5 ğ‘Š/ğ‘š We can now make an energy balance to calculate the increase in bulk temperature in a 3.0 m length of tube: ğ‘ = ğ‘šÌ‡ ğ‘ğ‘âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘ = ğ¿( ğ‘ ğ¿) We also have ğ‘šÌ‡ =ğœŒğ‘¢ğ‘š ğœ‹ğ‘‘2 4 = (1.493)(10)ğœ‹ (0.0254)2 4 =7.565Ã— 10âˆ’3 ğ‘˜ğ‘”/ğ‘  So that we insert the numerical values in the energy balance to obtain (7.565 Ã— 10âˆ’3)(1025)âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘ = (3.0)(103.5) and âˆ†ğ‘‡ğ‘ = 40.04â„ƒ
